questions.question: 1. In SCR, the magnitude of latching current (I<sub>L</sub>) compared to holding current (I<sub>H</sub>) is:

explanations.a: Explanation 1: The latching current is always higher than the holding current.

questions.question: 2. The v-i characteristics of SCR is a plot between:

explanations.b: Explanation 2: v-i characteristics shows the relation between the voltage across anode-to-cathode and the anode current.

questions.question: 3. The minimum value of anode current (i<sub>A</sub>) below which the SCR turns-OFF is called the

explanations.c: Explanation 3: Holding current is the minimum current required to keep SCR in conduction mode.

questions.question: 4. Under forward blocking state, the three junctions of the SCR (J1, J2 and J3) are in which states?

answers.c: 'J<sub>1</sub>, J<sub>3</sub>' are forward biased while 'J<sub>2</sub>' is reverse biased
answers.d: 'J<sub>1</sub>, J<sub>2</sub>' are forward biased while 'J<sub>3</sub>' is reverse biased

explanations.c: Explanation 3: During forward blocking J<sub>1</sub> and J<sub>2</sub> are forward biased because a positive Anode-to-Cathode voltage is applied. Whereas J<sub>2</sub>  is reverse biased due to the absence of gate current.

questions.question: 5. A SCR is triggered using a gate current. After sometime the gate signal is stopped. What is the status of SCR?

answers.c: SCR continues to conduct if anode current is maintained above latching current.
answers.d: SCR continues to conduct if anode current is maintained above holding current.

explanations.d: Explanation 4: SCR is a semi-controlled device i.e. once turned- ON (by gate current), it continues conducting even when gate pulse is removed (provided anode current is greater than the holding current).

questions.question: 6. A forward biased MOSFET comes into ON-state by?

explanations.c: Explanation 3: MOSFET is a voltage controlled device. Applying a positive Gate-to-Source voltage turns- ON the MOSFET.

questions.question: 7. In comparison to IGBT the losses in MOSFET are?

explanations.b: Explanation 2: IGBT has lower conduction losses compared to MOSFET.

questions.question: 8. Reliable method for firing an SCR is?

explanations.c: Explanation 3: SCR is a unidirectional device and allows current to flow only from Anode to Cathode when sufficient Gate current or firing pulses is applied.

questions.question: 9. In practice, the correct method of turning-ON a SCR is?

answers.a: Increasing the anode-to-cathode voltage (v<sub>AK</sub>) till it reaches a value equal to or above forward breakover voltage (v<sub>BO</sub>).
answers.b: The anode-to-cathode voltage (v<sub>AK</sub>) is maintained below the breakover voltage (v<sub>BO</sub>) and a positive voltage between the gate and cathode (V<sub>g</sub>) is applied across SCR.
answers.c: Increasing the anode-to-cathode voltage (v<sub>AK</sub>) till the anode current (i<sub>A</sub>) reaches above holding current (I<sub>H</sub>).
answers.d: Positive anode-to-cathode voltage (v<sub>AK</sub>) automatically turns- ON the SCR.

explanations.b: Explanation 2: SCR is turned- ON by forward biasing it and giving it sufficient gate current.

questions.question: 10. How can a conducting SCR be turned-OFF?

answers.a: By application of negative anode current (i<sub>A</sub>) or negative anode-to-cathode voltage (v<sub>AK</sub>).
answers.b: By application of negative gate current (I<sub>g</sub>).
answers.c: By reducing the gate current (I<sub>g</sub>) to zero.
answers.d: All of the above methods are correct.

explanations.a: Explanation 1: Applying negative anode current or negative anode-to-cathode voltage reverse biases the SCR, turning it OFF.

questions.question: 11. An IGBT is in ON- state. It is observed that with increasing collector-to-emitter voltage (V<sub>CE</sub>) the collector current (I<sub>C</sub>) is almost constant. Which region is the IGBT operating in?

explanations.c: Explanation 3: In saturation mode, the IGBT current remains constant even when Collector-to-emitter voltage is increased.

questions.question: 12. When compared to MOSFET  the time required to turn- OFF an IGBT is?

explanations.c: Explanation 3: Switching time of IGBT is greater than MOSFET due to the presence of tail current.
